Title: the line substitution solution

Penny: Helium.
Yes.
Yes. Pi.
More specific.
Yes.
Oh, that’s a Venn Diagram, and I remember because I thought to myself, venn is he gonna stop talking about this diagram?
Okay.
Sure.
No problem.
You really want me to pick up your mother all by myself?
Or a way for you to avoid her?
Fine, if you really want me to, I will pick your mom up.
Yeah, you know what, she is my mother-in-law, and I’d like for us to have a good relationship.
Okay.
Or as I know him?
Ding, ding, ding, ding, ding.
Wow. Didn’t even make it out of the parking lot. Uh, you know what, enough about Leonard. Let’s talk about you. What would you like to do while you’re here?
Well, I’d actually like for us to be close, but maybe we start with our favourite books and work our way up to my husband’s sex organs.
Um, does Pottery Barn, Spring count?
Uh, for starters, maybe you can not psychoanalyze everything I say?
Uncomfortable.
Oh. Sorry. Didn’t know you made those. Hey, listen, what if we have a little mother-in-law, daughter-in-law dinner tonight?
Or I invite a few girlfriends, ’cause hearing you say the two of us just sent a chill right down my spine.
You know, she’s my mother-in-law. Why can’t I bond with her like that?
You know, being in a relationship with Leonard also comes with its challenges.
Um, it has seat warmers.
How long have I had spinach in my teeth?
Okay, you know what? This is ridiculous. I’ve been trying to make a connection with you all day, and clearly I’m getting nowhere.
What I was seeking was some sort of friendship. But at this point, I’ll take you not insulting me to my face.
You’ve been doing it all day. Do you even know what an insult is?
Okay, good example.
To be honest, I’m surprised you cared about the wedding at all.
It was spur of the moment.
Thank you. So if we would have asked you to come to Vegas to see us get married, you would’ve come?
You really think we made a mistake?
Wow. Okay. Well, um, how about this? Maybe while you’re still in town, Leonard and I could have another small ceremony. You know, if you’re interested.
She would find it perfectly acceptable. You guys saw it. We bonded.
Sheldon: Yes.
Taylor Swift.
Yes. Kardashian.
Khloe?
See, I remembered because if it looks like Kim it’s Kim, if it looks kind of like Kim it’s Kourtney, and if it looks nothing like Kim it’s Khloe.
Oh, well, we decided to use our breakfast time to expand our respective knowledge bases.
I’m sorry, who is Mike Drop?
Why don’t you want to get your mother from the airport?
She can cover it in a car ride? I could do 40 minutes on your posture alone.
All right, back to learning.
Oh, easy, Bill Nye the Science Guy.
Creepy old dude from Dancing with the Stars.
Oh, well, I have a few questions for him about the last Avengers movie, and a whole lot of answers.
Oh, bad news. Amy’s making me go shopping with her later, so looks like none of us can go.
You’re really going without me?
You don’t have the authority to save places in the line. If I do that, I’ll be cutting.
You know the golden rule of line etiquette. No cuts, no buts, no coconuts.
Remember when we camped out for the Doctor Who panel at Comic-Con?
Stuart, what are you doing here?
I don’t understand. You were happy to do this when I hired you. Why, why are you upset with me now?
Well, I suppose turnabout is fair play.
Hey. Is everything smoothed out with Amy?
Did you make the apology as sincere as I would have?
Oh, well, that’s laying it on a little thick.
I suppose so. But if I get out of the line, I’ll lose my spot.
You would do that?
You’re a good man.
(Knock, knock, knock) Amy. (Knock, knock, knock) Amy. (Knock, knock, knock) Amy.

Hello, everyone. Oh, Beverly, good to see you. I’d love to chat, but there’s a line that could start moving any minute, so let’s do this. Amy? A proper apology requires three steps. Step one, an admission of wrongdoing. Amy, I was wrong. Step two, a promise never to repeat said action. Amy, that action will never be repeated, and that’s a promise. Step three, an earnest request for forgiveness. Amy, I hope you can forgive me. And I hope you do it right now, ’cause there’s an Uber waiting downstairs, and I don’t want to repeat this apology nonsense with my driver Ganesh.
Oh, thanks, you’re a peach. Beverly, we’ll catch up soon. Bernadette, it was a pleasure as always, Penny, you have spinach in your teeth.
I’m back.
It went well. Yeah, I’ve learned that if you never say you’re sorry, the times you do really puts them on their heels. Uh, Stuart, I relieve you of your line duties.
Did you see that? He just cut the line.
No, it’s not fine. It is a breach of line etiquette.
What if every person in front of us let someone cut?
What if each of those people let someone cut?
But then each of those people let someone cut?
Excuse me.
Uh, uh, I couldn’t help but notice that you cut the line.

Well, no. It’s not cool. If there were reserved seating, and we all had tickets, that would be fine. But this line is first-come, first-served. Not show up tardy and nevertheless be first served. Right here.
You need to go to the back of the line.
Mrs. Wunch in fourth grade. And my slogan was a line that’s straight is a line that’s great.
What about Joss Whedon’s work makes you think he’d be okay with rule-breakers and line-cutters?
They work for SHIELD, which is a sanctioned department of the U.S. Government. Do you work for a sanctioned department of the U.S. Government?
Excuse me, excuse me, can I please see a show of hands? Who here takes issue with this person cutting the line?
Well, what a sad state of affairs. That you’ve all been so ground down by life, you don’t even notice when someone disrespects you.

You know, right now, at the back of this line, there’s a movie fan like you who’s not going to get in, because this person simply doesn’t care. Yeah, well, 61 years ago, there was another person at the back of the line and her name was Rosa Parks.

Now, let’s follow in that brave woman’s footsteps, and stand up for ourselves. And, and I realize that she stood up by remaining seated, but now is not the time to enjoy the irony of that. Now, I ask you again. Who here takes issue with this person…
I most certainly did not.

Excuse me, I paid someone to wait in line for me, and then when I arrived, he left, so what you saw, my good woman, was swapsies, not cutsies. Oh, no, no, no, no, wait, I ask you all again, a show of hands. Who here takes issue… well, stop moving. he’s gonna get in.
No, I can’t. This isn’t right.
No, I could’ve done more.
Leonard: What are you guys doing?
Oh, let me try.
Hmm, atom of hydrogen, Adam of Maroon 5, mic drop.
Oh, hey, Penny, do you want to go to the airport with me later to pick up my mother?
Thanks.
Hey, Penny, um, since you’re already gonna be at the airport, do I need to go?
Well, I can do without the 40-minute car ride where she criticizes every aspect of my life.
Hmm, I just feel like it would be a good chance for you to bond.
I don’t know what he’s putting on those cards, but you are smarter than ever.
Seriously?
That is very mature of you, so I’m gonna go ahead and say, suckah.
When’s the screening?
Penny’s busy with my mother, so I’m in.
You do realize we’re allowed to have fun without you?
It’s not a big deal. Go shopping with Amy, and we’ll save a spot in line for you.
People do it all the time.
Waking up, wondering which one of those fans stole our wallets.
You think it’s time you apologize to her yourself?
So, when the aliens brought you back, they just left the probe in?
Hey, how’d it go?
We’d still get in.
Still get in.
We’d still get in, but first I’d hit you over the head with his stick chair.
Oh, please don’t.
No.
Boy, I wish I could say no.
Okay, you may have to pretend you’re black to get us out of here.
Buddy, let it go.
You did everything you could.
Now, now, you denigrated the memory of a great civil rights pioneer. That’s all anyone could ask.
Raj: Did you guys see there’s an Avengers screening? Joss Whedon’s gonna show some deleted scenes and do a question and answer session.
Uh, it’s tonight, but it’s first-come, first-served, so we should probably get there early and wait in line.
Yeah, sleeping under the stars with other fans who love the show as much as we do.
Boy, all this standing’s making me tired. Good thing I brought my collapsible stick chair.
Sticks and stones may break my bones, but chairs on sticks are comfy.
You can’t make me feel bad.
He’s got him there. The D even stands for department.
Howard: In fact, that’s usually the trick to it. What time do we need to get there?
If you really care that much, there are apps now that’ll let you hire people to do stuff like errands and wait in lines.
Some of these guys make over $20 an hour.
We’ve waited in a lot of lines together, haven’t we?
Not the stick chair. You look like an idiot on that thing.
You look like you come with a kickstand.
I’ll give you a dollar if you make fun of Raj.
Uh, if you ever need a reference or anything, just let me know.
We’re near the front of the line. We’ll get in either way.
I can’t believe we’re gonna get beat up, and it’s not because of your chair.
Stuart: People are actually waiting in lines as a job? Boy, makes me feel better about my life.
And now I feel worse again.
Hey.
I thought that might come up. Sheldon hired me to go shopping with you.
No, it’s not like that. There’s a long line he’d rather stand in. So what are we doing? Old Navy, Build-A-Bear? I get paid either way.
You sure? I’m happy to hold your bag. And Sheldon gave me money for a hotdog on a stick.
Look, lady, I just work here.
Sheldon, you are the most inconsiderate person I have ever met in my entire life. Where do you get off sending me to shop with your girlfriend?
Oh, I’m not upset with you, but Amy’s pretty bent out of shape, so she hired me to let you have it.
You’re darn right it’s fair play, you selfish jerk.
Sheldon says he’s sorry.
I would have done it for three.
Hey.
Uh, no, she’s still pretty mad.
I said, Sheldon says he’s sorry.
I’m happy to hold your place till you get back.
Consider it my way of getting more of your money.
Anyone else need anything before I go?
That’s mean.
You look like Tigger if Tigger looked like a jackass.
Beverly: I’m not surprised Leonard chose to avoid picking me up. He’s battled intimacy issues his whole life. Does he have difficulty maintaining erections?
Dear, I’m a psychiatrist. You don’t have to avoid having intimate conversations with me.
Very well. What’s the last book you read?
Penny, it’s only natural to want your mother-in-law to like you, and I acknowledge I can be an intimidating person. So what can I do to make this process easier for you?
And how does it make you feel when I psychoanalyze everything you say?
That was a joke, dear.
So just the two of us?
Maybe he couldn’t get a word in edgewise.
Oh, it’s all right, dear. Sheldon has a brilliant and complicated mind. It’s understandable that being in a relationship with him could be trying.
Well, I do admire your resolve. You’re an extraordinary woman.
Oh, well, that still could be a big step for Sheldon.
Yes. Well, what can you do?
Oh, I didn’t realize you two work together.
Oh, what are you currently developing?
That’s interesting. I just attended a lecture on pediatric anxiety.
It was.
Since the airport, dear.
That was very nice of Sheldon to apologize.
Your relationship with him is fascinating. I’m preparing to write a book on high-achieving couples, and I would love to interview the both of you.
Really? Do you think he would be interested in being interviewed as well?
Wonderful. I’ll give you my contact information.
About what?
Well, are you seeking a connection or just some form of validation?
My intention was never to insult you.
Well, it’s not a clinical term. But one example would be your marrying my son, and not inviting me or even telling me the wedding was taking place.
I’m still human, Penny. Not getting invited to my own son’s wedding is difficult to ignore.
I could’ve watched it on the Internet?
No, I would’ve said you’re making a huge mistake. But an invitation would’ve been nice.
At the time I did. But I’ve never seen Leonard so happy, so perhaps I was wrong.
I would find that perfectly acceptable.
Amy: What are you doing here? You’re not Sheldon.
Hold on. He paid you to get out of spending time with me?
Can you understand why I might be annoyed right now?

You know, just when I think we’re making progress in our relationship, we revert to our old patterns where thoughts and feelings go unexpressed. I mean, if he didn’t want to go shopping with me, why didn’t he just say so?
I’m sorry, I’ve been going on and on.
I called him babe once. He asked me to get a drug test.
Do you realize it took me five years to get a massage from him?
Three minutes. And he used a kitchen timer. I felt like a soft-boiled egg.
Bernadette, I’ll give you five dollars to slam the door.
Oh, was it, uh, Dr. Jenofski? I just saw his TED Talk.
Well, he’s come a long way. Or a short way very slowly, so it feels like a long way.
Oh, sure. I’ll, I’ll talk to Sheldon about it. You know, Bernadette’s husband is a former astronaut.
I know how you feel. She didn’t invite any of us.
Bernadette: Amy’s with Sheldon who she loves like a son. You’re with her son, who she doesn’t.
So, Beverly, did you know Penny is the number three sales rep at our pharmaceutical company?
Well, we don’t exactly. I’m a microbiologist for the research team.
Well, let’s get back to Penny. Hey, weren’t you telling me something great about your company car?
Do I think he’d be interested? Sometimes I hear him pretending to be interviewed when he’s alone in the bathroom.
Um, you should probably talk to Penny, too.
But we did get to see a live stream of it on the Internet.
Howie? You doing okay? You’ve been in there a while.
Amy (knock on door): Maybe it’s Sheldon, here to say he’s sorry.
Man: Oh, uh, I’m with my friends. It’s cool.
Uh, who made you line monitor?
The Avengers are rule-breakers. Being vengeful is in their job description.
As a matter of fact I do. At a little place called the DMV.
If you’re feeling dizzy, it’s because the tables have turned.
Woman: Why should we listen to you? You cut the line yourself.
Howard (through bathroom door): I’m fine. Be right out. Am I an American hero? Well, that’s a good question, Jim. Don’t you think once an astronaut leaves the planet, he’s a hero to all the nations of the Earth? Okey dokey. I think I have time for one more question.

She would find it perfectly acceptable. You guys saw it. We bonded.

I’m fine. Be right out. Am I an American hero? Well, that’s a good question, Jim. Don’t you think once an astronaut leaves the planet, he’s a hero to all the nations of the Earth? Okey dokey. I think I have time for one more question.
